variant.question: Ignoring the effect of compressibility, what would C~L~ do with an increase in altitude?

options.text: Remain the same.
Decrease.
Increase, then decrease.
Increase.

variant.question: An Operator is considering Johannesburg international airport as a new cargo destination. The aerodrome is at approximately 5 500 ft above mean sea level, and in summer the temperatures can reach 30° C. What effect should the operator consider these conditions might have on the maximum landing mass compared to standard atmosphere conditions at an aerodrome at mean sea level?

options.text: The maximum landing mass would be lower because the actual landing distances would increase.
The maximum landing mass would be the higher because the landing distances would decrease.
Warmer ambient temperatures affect the landing distance but NOT the landing mass.
There is NO effect on landing mass because standard atmosphere conditions are used when calculating the maximum landing mass.

variant.question: Johannesburg is at approximately 5 500 ft above mean sea level, and the temperatures can reach 30 °C in summer. What effect might these conditions have on the maximum landing mass compared to standard atmosphere conditions at an aerodrome at mean sea level?

options.text: The maximum landing mass would be lower because the actual landing distances would increase.
The maximum landing mass would be the higher because the landing distances would decrease.
There is no effect on landing mass because standard atmosphere conditions are used when calculating the maximum landing mass.
Warmer ambient temperatures affect the landing distance but not the landing mass.

variant.question: A pilot is planning a landing where the landing mass is greater the maximum quick turnaround mass. Select the correct statement that the pilot should follow

options.text: He must wait a certain amount of time before commencing another take-off.
He should increase the VREF to avoid a tailstrike on flare.
The autobrakes should not be selected.
He must not use the rapid exit taxiway.

variant.question: Given a paved, level, dry runway with NO wind and anti-skid serviceable, what would increase the field-length limited landing mass, assuming all other factors are constant?

options.text: a headwind
an inoperative anti-skid system
a wet runway surface.
a downhill slope

variant.question: What will increase the "Landing-Field Length-Limited landing mass" when operating with the anti-skid inoperative?

options.text: a headwind.
an increase in pressure altitude.
a contaminated runway.
a downslope.

variant.question: You are flying to a destination with limited fuel services and a short runway. To minimise fuel uplift requirements at the destination you plan to land with the maximum amount of fuel possible. What factor might limit your landing mass?

options.text: High OAT as it leads to a higher groundspeed.
A runway downslope as it leads to a reduced landing distance.
A runway upslope as it increases landing distance.
Low OAT as it leads to a lower groundspeed.

variant.question:
Our field length limited landing mass is affected by a number of variables, consider the variables listed below:


- Runway: paved, level (no slope)
- Condition: dry
- Wind: calm
- Anti-skid: operating

What difference to these variables would allow us to increase our field length limited landing mass?

options.text: Headwind.
Inoperative anti-skid system.
Downhill slope.
Wet runway.

variant.question: If the maximum Take-off Mass is limited by tire speed, what affect would a down sloping runway have?

options.text: No effect.
Only increase the mass if not limited by any other limitation.
Always increase the mass.
Decrease the mass.

variant.question:
Refer to figure 032-72.
Which of the figures represents the effect of landing gear extension on the total drag?

options.text: Figure 4
Figure 2
Figure 3
Figure 1

variant.question:
Figure 3.1
 Given
 OAT 24° C
 Pressure Altitude 3 000 ft
 RWY 12L
 Wind 080° /12 kts
 Take-off Mass 3 800 lbs
 Runway Surface Wet Grass - firm soil
 Runway Slope 2% downslope
 What is the minimum runway length? No stopway or clearway is available

Please refer to the annex or CAP 698 Figure 4.1. During an approach to land on runway 07 the controller informs the flight crew that the weather has changed significantly since the last report and the wind is now 220°(M)/25 kt. Considering that both runways 07 and 25 are fully operational and available, which of the following options provides the greatest performance safety margin?

options.text: There is a tailwind of approximately 22 kt on runway 07; the crew should request landing on runway 25 instead.
Runway 07 only has a tailwind of 7 kt and a normal approach and landing on runway 07 should continue.
The 22 kt headwind on runway 07 means the crew should continue the approach and land on runway 07.
There is a headwind of 12 kt on runway 25 and a request to land on it should be considered.

variant.question:
Refer to figure or CAP 698 figure 3.9. 
 What is the required minimum landing distance available for MEP1 according to EU-OPS? 
  
 Landing surface: wet grass 
 Temp +30ºC 
 Altitude: MSL 
 Weight: 4 300 lb 
 Headwind component: 5 kts

The operator of a commercial jet transport aeroplane plans to open a new route to an aerodrome with a high field elevation. In summer, it is often affected by low pressure systems and temperatures can reach up to 30°C. What will be the likely effect on maximum landing mass, compared to an aerodrome at sea level (ISA conditions)?

options.text: The MLM will be decreased.
The MLM will be increased.
The MLM will remain fairly constant as the pressure difference compensates for the higher temperature.
The MLM will increase slightly as the temperature difference compensates for the lower pressure.

variant.question: The runway slope must be used for scheduled landing mass calculations for a performance class A airplane, when...

options.text: the slope exceeds ±2 %.
the runway is available in both directions.
the runway is available in one direction only and with a tailwind component.
landing into the wind.

variant.question: How does runway slope affect allowable take-off mass, assuming other factors remain constant and not limiting?

options.text: A downhill slope increases allowable take-off mass.
A downhill slope decreases allowable take-off mass.
An uphill slope increases the allowable take-off mass.
Allowable take-off mass is not affected by runway slope.

variant.question: A medium size commercial jet airliner prepares for landing. The runway is now reported as wet with a 5 kt tailwind, a result of a recent storm passing through the aerodrome. How do these new conditions affect the actual maximum landing mass, when compared to the planned landing on a dry runway with still wind?

options.text: The wind and runway conditions will decrease the maximum landing mass.
The wind and runway conditions will increase the maximum landing mass by increasing the landing distance.
The wind and runway surface will NOT affect the maximum landing mass, they only affect the landing distance.
The wind will decrease the maximum landing mass, but the surface condition will increase the maximum landing mass.

variant.question: In case of landing on a flooded runway and in heavy rain: - you increase your approach speed. - you land firmly in order to obtain a firm contact of the wheels with the runway and immediately land your nose gear. - you decrease your approach speed. - you use systematically all the lift dumper devices. - you land as smoothly as possible. - you brake energetically. The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
To minimise the risk of hydroplaning during landing the pilot should:

options.text: make a “positive” landing and apply maximum reverse thrust and brakes as quickly as possible.
use maximum reverse thrust, and should start braking below the hydroplaning speed.
postpone the landing until the risk of hydroplaning no longer exists.
use normal landing-, braking- and reverse technique.

variant.question: To minimise the risk of hydroplaning during landing the pilot should:

options.text: make a positive landing and apply maximum reverse thrust and brakes as quickly as possible.
postpone the landing until the risk of hydroplaning no longer exists.
use maximum reverse thrust, and should start braking below the hydroplaning speed.
use normal landing-, braking- and reverse technique.

variant.question: To minimize the risk of hydroplaning during landing the pilot should:

options.text: make a "positive" landing and apply maximum reverse thrust and brakes as quickly as possible.
postpone the landing until, the risk of hydroplaning no longer exists.
use normal landing, braking and reverse technique.
use maximum reverse thrust, and should start braking below the hydroplaning speed.

variant.question: At a tropical airfield during the rainy season, heavy rain showers often cause the runways to be very wet. Which of the following landing techniques should be used when landing on these runways?

options.text: Positive landings with prompt full application of all retardation devices and maximum brake/autobrake with anti-skid.
Use of reverse thrust should be kept to a minimum to avoid water spray and ingestion; anti-skid braking should be applied slowly to avoid hydroplaning.
The pilot should maintain normal approach and landing technique but use a slower approach and landing speed compared to dry runway operations.
Landings should be made with light touchdowns, maximum air brake and reverse thrust but minimum anti-skid braking.

variant.question: What increases your landing-field length limited mass when your anti-skid is inoperative?

options.text: Headwind
Increase in Pressure Altitude
Contaminated runway
Downslope

variant.question: The maximum allowed depth of wet snow covering the runway is...

options.text: 30 mm
50 mm
13 mm
10 mm

variant.question: The runway limited take-off mass on a dry runway is the maximum take-off mass for the given airport/runway conditions, considering...

options.text: TODA, TORA, ASDA and flap position.
TODA, ASDA, use of available reverse thrust and flap position.
TORA and flap position.
TODA, TORA, ASDA, use of available reverse thrust and flap position.

variant.question: The runway limited take-off mass on a dry runway is the maximum take-off mass for the given airport/runway conditions, considering

options.text: TODA, TORA, ASDA and flap position.
TODA, TORA, ASDA, use of available reverse thrust and flap position.
TODA, ASDA, use of available reverse thrust and flap position.
TORA and flap position.

variant.question: In comparison to manual braking, how do autobrakes affect the landing distance?

options.text: Decrease landing distance by maintaining selected autobrakes
Increase landing distance by maintaining maximum autobrakes
Increase landing distance by maintaining selected autobrakes
Decrease landing distance by maintaining maximum autobrakes

variant.question:
Which of the following items can limit the Maximum Permissible Landing Mass for a Quick Turnaround?

1. Aerodrome pressure altitude2. Aerodrome temperature3. Air conditioning packs ON/OFF4. Flap setting5. Runway slope6. Use of reverse thrust7. Wind component
You are departing Mykonos (Greece) and taking off on a runway facing towards the sea. The runway is classed as a short field. What of the following is most likely to be the limiting mass?

options.text: Field length limited takeoff mass.
Obstacle limited takeoff mass.
Climb limited takeoff mass.
Tyre limit takeoff mass.

variant.question: Which statement regarding the influence of a runway down-slope is correct for a balanced take-off? - Down-slope...

options.text: reduces V1 and reduces take-off distance required (TODR).
reduces V1 and increases the accelerate stop distance required (ASDR).
increases V1 and reduces the accelerate stop distance required (ASDR).
increases V1 and increases the take-off distance required (TODR).

variant.question:
Refer to the annex. A Medium Range Jet Transport is planned to depart from Gran Canaria runway 21L or 21R. When running the performance software to find the Maximum Allowed Take-Off Mass, the following 2 masses are presented: 
Runway 21 L : 91.4 tonnes. 
Runway 21 R : 90.9 tonnes.
Assume that the runways have the same slope. What is one possible reason for this difference in the Maximum Allowed Take-Off Mass?

options.text: More limiting obstacles are within the obstacle domain for runway 21R compared to runway 21L, requiring a greater climb gradient.
The runways are field-length-limited and each runway will have its own individual Field-Length-Limiting Take-Off Mass.
Runway 21L has more limiting close-in obstacles than runway 21R and requires a greater climb gradient in the second segment.
The runways are climb-limited with the obstacle domains being the same since the runways are close together with parallel thresholds.

variant.question:
In case of landing on a flooded runway and in stormy conditions you will:1. increase your approach speed, 
 2. land firmly in order to obtain a firm contact of the wheels with the runway and immediately land your nose gear, 
 3. decrease your approach speed, 
 4. use systematically all the lift dumper devices, 
 5. land as smoothly as possible, 
 6. apply maximum braking pressure 
 7. apply brakes up to antiskid activationThe combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
For a performance class A airplane, when must the runway slope be used for scheduled landing mass calculations?

options.text: When the slope exceeds ± 2%.
When landing into the wind with an engine failure.
When the runway is available in both directions.
When the runway is available in one direction only and with a tailwind component.

variant.question: An aircraft is approaching a wet runway in stormy conditions. What should the pilot do?

options.text: Increased approach speed.
Decreased approach speed.
Fly a steeper approach path.
Use full anti-skid braking with a firm touchdown.
